title: Typeface that goes with Woodcarver Normal and Rosewood...but can be very small
content:
Help me out please,

I am doing a vintage bluegrass meets elegant invite using Woodcarver and Rosewood. I need something for the fine print that looks like Woodcarver Normal...but is much easier to read in a small size. Although I am open to suggestion if something else would go better with those two Display typefaces.

thanks in advance!
author: shielddesign

comments.content: Well I'd personally avoid woodcarver (assuming you're talking about [ICG Carver](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415023031/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/imageclub/carver/)). It doesn't fit the mold of old letterpressed woodtype and it's pretty illegible at any size. I think [Corner Bakery](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415023031/http:/www.cornerbakery.com/) does a decent job of incorporating different faces for a rustic quasi-show card feel. Perhaps combine Rosewood & Rosewood Fill with some other woodtype faces like [Brothers](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415023031/http:/emigre.com/EF.php?fid=83), [Council](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415023031/http:/emigre.com/EF.php?fid=86), or some of the [Adobe woodtypes](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415023031/http:/store1.adobe.com/cfusion/store/html/index.cfm?store=OLS-US&event=searchFonts&type=category&cat=theme&code=old-west)

Nope it is a very nice script font...I agree ICG Carver is icky. I need a feminine font since it is a wedding invite for a chef and her blue-grass husband.

Here is the woodcarver font...see it's nice big, but lousy small.

[http://www.free-fonts-ttf.org/true-type-fonts/woodcarver-normal-2586-dow...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415023031/http:/www.free-fonts-ttf.org/true-type-fonts/woodcarver-normal-2586-download.htm "http://www.free-fonts-ttf.org/true-type-fonts/woodcarver-normal-2586-download.htm")

On a side note, I hope you are fixing the spacing problems of "Woodcarver." Pleasant letterforms, but the spacing is badly broken, especially the "d" and "f"....

Cheers,

T

Thomas...thanks for the great tip. Since there is so little copy on this I am pretty much hand kerning it all. i did however notice what you mean on the d...very odd...I also had to bring the dot on the i closer to the i.

You sound like a man who would have a great typeface suggestion I could use with these two fonts (woodcarver is dominant with rosewood playing a lesser role...but the details of the event (rehearsal dinner) are unreadable even in in 11pt.

thanks!
